elements.content: A new series of mixed ligand based coordination polymers (CPs) has been synthesized by reacting a new ligand, namely, hpdia (5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalic acid); various bispyridyl coligands (2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy), and 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpe)); and Zn­(NO3)2/Cd­(NO3)2 under solvothermal conditions. The molecular structure of hpdia was established by analyzing the single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) data of the sodium salt of hpdia which turned out to be an alkali coordination polymer with a formula [(H2O)4Na2(μ-hpdia)4]∞ (CP1). SXRD analyses of the other transition metal compounds, thus synthesized, revealed that they were all coordination polymers (except DCC3a discrete coordination complex) having formulas [{(H2O)­Zn­(μ-hpdia)­(2,2′-bpy)}·H2O]∞ (CP2), [(H2O)­Zn2(μ-hpdia)2(2,2′-bpy)2]2 (DCC3), [{(H2O)­Cd­(μ-hpdia)­(2,2′-bpy)}·H2O]∞ (CP4), [{(H2O)­Zn­(μ-hpdia)­(4,4′-bpy)}·H2O]∞ (CP5), [Zn0.5(hpdia)­(μ-4,4′-bpy)0.5]∞ (CP6), [{(H2O)2Cd2(μ-hpdia)2(μ-4,4′-bpy)}·2H2O]∞ (CP7), and [{Zn2(μ-hpdia)2(μ-bpe)}·H2O]∞ (CP8). The majority of the CPs were lattice occluded molecular solids. Remarkably, the reactants of all of the coordination polymers and also DCC3 showed the ability to produce metallogels which were characterized by rheology and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The results supported the structural consideration based on which these metallogelators were designed.

elements.content:
A hitherto unexplored bicarboxylate ligand has been exploited in a new series of mixed ligand coordination polymers to produce metallogels.

Introduction

Metallogels (MGs) are soft viscoelastic materials wherein a large volume of liquid (gelling solvents) is immobilized (gelled) within a 3D network generated by coordination linkage between organic ligands and metal centers that include discrete coordination complexes, infinite coordination polymers, and crossed-linked coordination polymers (CPs). Noncoordinating metal ions within the gel matrix in supramolecular gels are shown to act as growth regulators for the preparation of metallic nanoparticles or as templates for the formation of porous or nanoimprinted supramolecular assemblies and greatly influence the morphology and kinetics of gel formation. Because of the various potential applications such as in catalysis, sensing, optics, and magnetic materials etc., research on metallogels has witnessed an upsurge. Like supramolecular gelators, designing metallogelators is also extremely difficult as the molecular level structural information on the gel network is poorly understood. Nonetheless, there have been efforts to design metallogelators; for example, aborting crystallization by increasing the randomness of mixed ligand carboxylates of AgI coordination compounds, appending a well-known gel forming fragment (aromatic-linker-steroid or ALS) to an organometallic moiety, introducing long alkyl chains on a coordination complex, flexible ligand coordination, and slow formation of coordination polymers, etc., have all been demonstrated to have induced metallogelation. Our group has successfully exploited a supramolecular synthon approach to design metallogelators derived from ferrocene derivatives.

A hitherto unexplored bicarboxylate ligand has been exploited in a new series of mixed ligand coordination polymers to produce metallogels.

Introduction

Metallogels (MGs) are soft viscoelastic materials wherein a large volume of liquid (gelling solvents) is immobilized (gelled) within a 3D network generated by coordination linkage between organic ligands and metal centers that include discrete coordination complexes, infinite coordination polymers, and crossed-linked coordination polymers (CPs). Noncoordinating metal ions within the gel matrix in supramolecular gels are shown to act as growth regulators for the preparation of metallic nanoparticles or as templates for the formation of porous or nanoimprinted supramolecular assemblies and greatly influence the morphology and kinetics of gel formation. Because of the various potential applications such as in catalysis, sensing, optics, and magnetic materials etc., research on metallogels has witnessed an upsurge. Like supramolecular gelators, designing metallogelators is also extremely difficult as the molecular level structural information on the gel network is poorly understood. Nonetheless, there have been efforts to design metallogelators; for example, aborting crystallization by increasing the randomness of mixed ligand carboxylates of AgI coordination compounds, appending a well-known gel forming fragment (aromatic-linker-steroid or ALS) to an organometallic moiety, introducing long alkyl chains on a coordination complex, flexible ligand coordination, and slow formation of coordination polymers, etc., have all been demonstrated to have induced metallogelation. Our group has successfully exploited a supramolecular synthon approach to design metallogelators derived from ferrocene derivatives.

elements.content: There have been various efforts toward the understanding and design of gelators that were based on the structural aspects of gelator molecules. For example, Shinkai et al. proposed, based on a few single crystal structures of sugar derivatives, that 1D hydrogen bonded network was important for gelationa working hypothesis that was supported by a large number of single crystal structures of gelator and nongelators reported by our group. George and Weiss provided important information about the molecular packing of the gelator molecules in the neat powder samples and their gels. Liu et al. and Rogers et al. described an interesting crystallographic mismatch branching mechanism for gelation. Adams et al. provided important insights into the gelation and crystallization behavior of two closely related dipeptides by invoking computational studies. Almost a decade ago, Wuest et al. proposed and demonstrated that molecules that were prone to form lattice occluded molecular solids were a potential target as gelators since, in both cases (lattice occluded molecular solids and gels), a large volume of solvents were entrapped within a network. Following this alternative approach, we have successfully developed metallogelators derived from various coordination polymers; in these studies, we typically exploited hydrogen bond functionalized multidentate ligands that produced various MGs. We have also generated catalytically active metal nanoparticles from MGs.

For example, Shinkai et al. proposed, based on a few single crystal structures of sugar derivatives, that 1D hydrogen bonded network was important for gelationa working hypothesis that was supported by a large number of single crystal structures of gelator and nongelators reported by our group. George and Weiss provided important information about the molecular packing of the gelator molecules in the neat powder samples and their gels. Liu et al. and Rogers et al. described an interesting crystallographic mismatch branching mechanism for gelation. Adams et al. provided important insights into the gelation and crystallization behavior of two closely related dipeptides by invoking computational studies. Almost a decade ago, Wuest et al. proposed and demonstrated that molecules that were prone to form lattice occluded molecular solids were a potential target as gelators since, in both cases (lattice occluded molecular solids and gels), a large volume of solvents were entrapped within a network. Following this alternative approach, we have successfully developed metallogelators derived from various coordination polymers; in these studies, we typically exploited hydrogen bond functionalized multidentate ligands that produced various MGs. We have also generated catalytically active metal nanoparticles from MGs.

elements.content: In this work, we adopt a similar approach to develop MGs. We report on a series of metallogelators derived from mixed ligand based coordination polymers; herein we have exploited a hitherto unexplored dicarboxylate ligand, namely, (5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalic acid) (hpdia); various bispyridyl ligands, namely, 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy), and 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpe); and Zn­(NO3)2/Cd­(NO3)2 (). While angularly placed carboxylate coordinating sites in hpdia are expected to coordinate the metal centers to generate coordination polymers, the terminal hydroxyl functionality will provide hydrogen bonding sites to invite guest molecules (solvates) to be occluded in the crystal lattice. Photoresponsiveness of the azo moiety of hpdia is not expected in the resulting CPs because it requires the pendent phenolic moiety to move in space while going from trans to cis and vice versa, which we anticipate to be restricted because of the participation of phenolic -OH in strong hydrogen bonding. All of the CPs were characterized by SXRD, and also by FT-IR, TGA, and elemental analyses. The results revealed that the majority of the CPs were lattice occluded molecular solids as envisaged. Remarkably, the dicarboxylate ligand hpdia and the reactants of all of the CPs were able to gel various aqueous solvents. The gels were characterized by SEM and rheology.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out using a PerkinElmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded using PerkinElmer Spectrum GX. The mass spectra were recorded with a Q-TOF Micro YA 263 mass spectrometer. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out using a PerkinElmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded using PerkinElmer Spectrum GX. The mass spectra were recorded with a Q-TOF Micro YA 263 mass spectrometer. NMR spectra (1H and 13C) were recorded using a 500 MHz Bruker Avance Ultrashield Plus spectrometer.

elements.content: To a solution of dimethyl-5-aminoisophthalate (10 mmol, 2.1 g) in 20 mL of H2O was added 1 mL of concentrated HCl; the solution was cooled to 5 °C. A solution of NaNO2 (11 mmol, 0.75 g) in 2 mL of ice cold water was added dropwise with vigorous stirring. In a separate flask, a mixture of phenol (12 mmol, 1.13 g) and CH3COONa (110 mmol, 9 g) in 20 mL of ice water was prepared. The diazonium solution was added to the phenolic solution dropwise over 20 min with vigorous stirring. The mixture was allowed to warm up to room temperature naturally and then filtered and washed with distilled water (3 × 100 mL). The orange-red precipitate was air-dried to yield 2.9 g, 92% dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalate. In a typical hydrolysis reaction dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalate was added to a round-bottom flask containing methanol (150 mL). An aqueous NaOH solution (6 g in 20 mL of H2O) was added to this mixture and then refluxed at 50 °C/(12 h). The solution was acidified to pH = 1 using concentrated HCl. The precipitate was separated by filtration and washed with cold H2O to yield 2.5 g, 88% 5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalic acid. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C14H10N2O5 (%): C, 58.74; H, 3.52; N, 9.79. Found: C, 58.61; H, 3.58; N, 9.69. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 10.51 (s), 8.54 (s), 8.45 (2H, s), 7.88–7.86 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz), 6.98–6.96 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz). 13C NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 166.82, 161.80, 152.13, 145.10, 134.23, 131.15, 125.71, 125.28, 116.16. UV–vis λmax (nm): 349, 249, 237. ESI-MS. Calcd for C14H10N2O5: 287.24 (M + 1). Found: [M + Na]+ 309.04. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1, ): 3390, 1704, 1600, 1506, 1417, 1319, 1271, 1234, 1149, 1108, 979, 919, 838, 759, 744, 605.

elements.clean_text:
Syntheses and Characterization of CPs

[(H2O)4Na2(μ-hpdia)4]∞ (CP1)

Na-hpdia was obtained by reacting hpdia with NaOH in 1:2 molar ratios in aqueous solution and drying. X-ray quality crystals of CP1 were grown by slow evaporation of dilute ethanolic solution of Na-hpdia at room temperature. After 3 weeks X-ray quality needle shaped orange crystals were obtained. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C56H42N8Na2O24 (%): C, 53.51; H, 3.37; N, 8.91. Found: C, 52.99; H, 3.48; N, 8.87. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3267, 3083, 1716, 1591, 1504, 1409, 1338, 1263, 1222, 1149, 1105, 977, 918, 837, 761, 746, 680.

elements.content: CP2 and DCC3 were obtained concomitantly under solvothermal condition from a DMF/methanol/water solution (1:2:3) of a mixture of hpdia (28.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.01 mmol) and 2,2′-bpy (15.7 mg, 0.01 mmol). The mixture was taken in a 25 mL torsion vial, heated at 75 °C for 48 h, and allowed to cool slowly. After cooling, block shaped yellow crystals were isolated (). Elem. Anal. Calcd for C24H20N4O7Zn (CP2; %): C, 53.20; H, 3.72; N, 10.34. Found: C, 53.55; H, 3.43; N, 10.36. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3353, 1600, 1554, 1539, 1440, 1371, 1249, 1145, 1025, 845, 763, 730. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C48H34N8O11Zn2 (DCC3; %): C, 55.99; H, 3.32; N, 10.88. Found: C, 55.42; H, 3.39; N, 10.54. For concomitant compounds, the corresponding crystals were handpicked under a microscope for elemental analysis. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3158, 1614, 1587, 1558, 1506, 1477, 1446, 1361, 1269, 1213, 1139, 847, 765, 732.

elements.content: In a typical gelation experiment, the ligand hpdia was dissolved in 50 μL of DMF/DMSO to get a clear solution and mixed with 450 μL of water at room temperature in a 5 mL glass vial so that the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 1:9 (v/v). The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method.
elements.clean_text:
Gelation

In a typical gelation experiment, the ligand hpdia was dissolved in 50 μL of DMF/DMSO to get a clear solution and mixed with 450 μL of water at room temperature in a 5 mL glass vial so that the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 1:9 (v/v). The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method.

elements.content: In a typical gelation experiment, a mixture of ligand and co-ligand was dissolved in 100 μL of DMF/DMSO to obtain a clear solution and mixed with 400 μL of aqueous solution of corresponding metal salt at room temperature in a 5 mL glass vial so that the metal/ligand/co-ligand molar ratio was 1:1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 1:4 (v/v). The gel formed by sonication for 5–10 s. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method.
elements.clean_text:
Metallogelation

In a typical gelation experiment, a mixture of ligand and co-ligand was dissolved in 100 μL of DMF/DMSO to obtain a clear solution and mixed with 400 μL of aqueous solution of corresponding metal salt at room temperature in a 5 mL glass vial so that the metal/ligand/co-ligand molar ratio was 1:1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 1:4 (v/v). The gel formed by sonication for 5-10 s. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method.

elements.content: T gels of the gels obtained from hpdia were measured by dropping ball method. In a typical experiment, a glass ball weighing 216.45 mg was placed on a 0.5 mL gel taken in a test tube (15 × 100 mmol). The test tube was then immersed in an oil bath placed on a hot plate. The temperature was noted when the ball touched the bottom of the test tube.
elements.clean_text:
Gel-Sol Dissociation Temperature (T gel)

 T gels of the gels obtained from hpdia were measured by dropping ball method. In a typical experiment, a glass ball weighing 216.45 mg was placed on a 0.5 mL gel taken in a test tube (15 × 100 mmol). The test tube was then immersed in an oil bath placed on a hot plate. The temperature was noted when the ball touched the bottom of the test tube.

SEM micrographs were recorded using a JEOL, JSM-6700F. Sample preparation involved smearing a small quantity of freshly prepared gel on an SEM stub, which was then dried in air.

Rheology Studies

The rheological response of ligand hpdia and all of the CPs metallogels were studied under dynamic and steady shear measurement at room temperature (25 °C) on parallel-plate geometry (25 mm diameter, 1 mm gap). Rheological experiments were carried out using and Anton Paar modular compact rheometer (MCR 102).

elements.content: Suitable, apparently single crystals of all the CPs were selected. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined using full matrix least-squares method, based on F 2 values against all reflections, which was performed by SHELXL-2014/7.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Suitable, apparently single crystals of all the CPs were selected. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined using full matrix least-squares method, based on F 2 values against all reflections, which was performed by SHELXL-2014/7.

elements.content: Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å) diffractometer in the 5–35° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second. The sample was prepared by making a thin film from the finely powdered sample (∼30 mg) over a glass slide. For concomitant compounds, the corresponding crystals were handpicked under a microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å) diffractometer in the 5-35° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second. The sample was prepared by making a thin film from the finely powdered sample (~30 mg) over a glass slide. For concomitant compounds, the corresponding crystals were handpicked under a microscope.

elements.content: The ligand hpdia was synthesized by reacting diazonium salt of dimethyl-5-aminoisophthalate with sodium phenoxide followed by hydrolysis. Several attempts to crystallize hpdia resulted in thin fibers not suitable for SXRD. In order to establish the molecular structure of the ligand hpdia, it was reacted with NaOH with the hope of isolating the corresponding sodium salt crystals suitable for SXRD. In fact, such reaction resulted in isolation of X-ray quality crystals that turned out to be a salt coordination polymer CP1. The crystals of the other ZnII/CdII CPs, namely, CP2 and DCC3-CP8, were obtained by solvothermal reactions in DMF–methanol–water solutions (1:2:3) containing the corresponding reactants in 1:1:1 molar ratio. Crystallographic data, bond length and bond angles for all of the crystals were listed in the and , respectively. ORTEP plots of CP1–CP8 along with their hydrogen bonding parameters were listed in Figures S6–S13.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

The ligand hpdia was synthesized by reacting diazonium salt of dimethyl-5-aminoisophthalate with sodium phenoxide followed by hydrolysis. Several attempts to crystallize hpdia resulted in thin fibers not suitable for SXRD. In order to establish the molecular structure of the ligand hpdia, it was reacted with NaOH with the hope of isolating the corresponding sodium salt crystals suitable for SXRD. In fact, such reaction resulted in isolation of X-ray quality crystals that turned out to be a salt coordination polymer CP1. The crystals of the other ZnII/CdII CPs, namely, CP2 and DCC3-CP8, were obtained by solvothermal reactions in DMF-methanol-water solutions (1:2:3) containing the corresponding reactants in 1:1:1 molar ratio. Crystallographic data, bond length and bond angles for all of the crystals were listed in the  and , respectively. ORTEP plots of CP1-CP8 along with their hydrogen bonding parameters were listed in  Figures S6-S13.

SXRD analysis of the single crystal isolated by slow evaporation of an ethanolic solution of Na-hpdia revealed that it belonged to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of four hpdia of which two were monodeprotonated at the -COOH functionality, two Na atoms, and four coordinated water molecules. Interestingly, the Na+ cations, instead of being involved in just electrostatic interactions with the carboxylate moieties, are also involved in coordination with the O atoms of the phenolic -OH and carbonyl moieties. Both Na metal centers display distorted octahedral coordination geometry, each coordinated by two phenolic O atoms, two carbonyl O atoms, and two water molecules. The overall coordination network may best be described as a 2D-coordination polymeric network that runs parallel to the ac-plane. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion sustained by COOH···–OOC hydrogen bonding. Besides, the phenolic aryl rings are involved in intrasheet π···π interactions (Cg···Cg = 3.745–3.828 Å; ).

SXRD analysis of the single crystal isolated by slow evaporation of an ethanolic solution of Na-hpdia revealed that it belonged to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of four hpdia of which two were monodeprotonated at the -COOH functionality, two Na atoms, and four coordinated water molecules. Interestingly, the Na+ cations, instead of being involved in just electrostatic interactions with the carboxylate moieties, are also involved in coordination with the O atoms of the phenolic -OH and carbonyl moieties. Both Na metal centers display distorted octahedral coordination geometry, each coordinated by two phenolic O atoms, two carbonyl O atoms, and two water molecules. The overall coordination network may best be described as a 2D-coordination polymeric network that runs parallel to the ac-plane. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion sustained by COOH⋅⋅⋅-OOC hydrogen bonding. Besides, the phenolic aryl rings are involved in intrasheet π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (Cg⋅⋅⋅Cg = 3.745-3.828 Å; ).

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one ZnII, one hpdia, one 2,2′-bpy, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice occluded water molecule. The ZnII metal center displays trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry (τ5 = 0.59); the equatorial sites are coordinated by one pyridyl N atom, and two carboxylate O atoms whereas the apical positions are occupied by the coordinated water and pyridyl N atom. The hpdia ligand displays a bis-monodentate bridging mode resulting in a 1D-coordination polymeric chain running along the b-axis. Such 1D chains are packed in parallel fashion sustained by O–H···O hydrogen bonding involving the phenolic -OH and the carboxylate resulting in a 2D hydrogen bonded network. The 2D sheets are further packed in an opposite fashion via O–H···O interactions involving the metal bound water and phenolic -OH. The solvate water molecules are located within the interstitial space of the network sustained via O–H···O interactions with the carboxylate moiety as well as C–H···O interactions involving the pyridyl C–H. Reasonably strong π···π interactions (Cg···Cg = 3.594 Å) involving the pendant aryl ring and the pyridyl moieties are also observed ().

The asymmetric unit consists of one ZnII, one hpdia, one 2,2'-bpy, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice occluded water molecule. The ZnII metal center displays trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry (τ5 = 0.59); the equatorial sites are coordinated by one pyridyl N atom, and two carboxylate O atoms whereas the apical positions are occupied by the coordinated water and pyridyl N atom. The hpdia ligand displays a bis-monodentate bridging mode resulting in a 1D-coordination polymeric chain running along the b-axis. Such 1D chains are packed in parallel fashion sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding involving the phenolic -OH and the carboxylate resulting in a 2D hydrogen bonded network. The 2D sheets are further packed in an opposite fashion via O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the metal bound water and phenolic -OH. The solvate water molecules are located within the interstitial space of the network sustained via O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions with the carboxylate moiety as well as C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the pyridyl C-H. Reasonably strong π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (Cg⋅⋅⋅Cg = 3.594 Å) involving the pendant aryl ring and the pyridyl moieties are also observed ().

elements.content: The crystal of DCC3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two ZnII, two hpdia, two 2,2′-bpy, and one coordinated water molecule. The two ZnII metal centers display different coordination geometrydistorted trigonal bipyramidal (τ5 = 0.39) and distorted square pyramidal (τ5 = 0.27); the equatorial positions of the former geometry are occupied by two N atoms of the bipyridyl moiety and one O atom of the carboxylate whereas the apical positions are coordinated by a water and carboxylate O atom. In distorted square pyramidal geometry, the equatorial positions were occupied by the pyridyl N atoms and carboxylate O atoms coordinated via chelating mode and the axial position is occupied by carboxylate O atom. The coordination network of DCC3 may be best described as a discrete coordination complex of M4L4 type wherein the opposite metal centers of the metalla-macrocyle adopt distorted trigonal bipyramidal and distorted square pyramidal geometry. The relative orientation of the ligand hpdia with respect to its phenolic moiety is found to be up–up–down–down in the coordination complex. The macrocyclic rings are further packed on top of each other along the a-axis sustained by O–H···O hydrogen bond involving the phenolic -OH and carboxylate. Such stacks of macrocycles are packed in parallel fashion again sustained by O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions. No lattice occluded solvent molecule is found in the crystal structure presumably because of the efficient packing of the macrocycles ().

Crystal Structure of [(H2O)Zn2(μ-hpdia)2(2,2'-bpy)2]2 (DCC3)

The crystal of DCC3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two ZnII, two hpdia, two 2,2'-bpy, and one coordinated water molecule. The two ZnII metal centers display different coordination geometrydistorted trigonal bipyramidal (τ5 = 0.39) and distorted square pyramidal (τ5 = 0.27); the equatorial positions of the former geometry are occupied by two N atoms of the bipyridyl moiety and one O atom of the carboxylate whereas the apical positions are coordinated by a water and carboxylate O atom. In distorted square pyramidal geometry, the equatorial positions were occupied by the pyridyl N atoms and carboxylate O atoms coordinated via chelating mode and the axial position is occupied by carboxylate O atom. The coordination network of DCC3 may be best described as a discrete coordination complex of M4L4 type wherein the opposite metal centers of the metalla-macrocyle adopt distorted trigonal bipyramidal and distorted square pyramidal geometry. The relative orientation of the ligand hpdia with respect to its phenolic moiety is found to be up-up-down-down in the coordination complex. The macrocyclic rings are further packed on top of each other along the a-axis sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond involving the phenolic -OH and carboxylate. Such stacks of macrocycles are packed in parallel fashion again sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions. No lattice occluded solvent molecule is found in the crystal structure presumably because of the efficient packing of the macrocycles ().

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP4 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one CdII, one hpdia, one 2,2′-bpy, one coordinated water, and one lattice occluded water molecule. The CdII metal center displays distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, coordinated by two chelating carboxylates and one pyridyl N atom in equatorial position while the axial positions are occupied by water and one pyridyl N atom. The hpdia ligand displays a chelating coordination fashion resulting in a 1D-coordination polymeric chain; such 1D chains are arranged in a parallel fashion sustained by O–H···O hydrogen bonding involving the phenolic -OH and carboxylate of the interacting chains resulting in a 2D hydrogen bonded sheet. The 2D sheets are further interacted with each other in opposite fashion via O–H···O interactions involving the phenolic -OH and carboxylate of the interacting sheets. The solvate water is involved in hydrogen bonding to carboxylate O atoms via O–H···O interactions. The network is also sustained by π···π interactions involving pyridyl rings and pendant aryl rings (Cg···Cg = 3.534–3.881 Å) ().

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP5 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one ZnII, one hpdia, one 4,4′-bpy, one coordinated water, and one lattice occluded water molecule. The ZnII metal center displays slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (τ4 = 0.84), coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms, one water, and one pyridyl N atom. The hpdia ligand displays a bis-monodentate coordination resulting in a 1D-coordination polymeric chain along the a-axis; the monocoordinated 4,4′-bpy remains on one side of the 1D chain; such 1D chains are packed in antiparallel fashion sustained by O–H···O interactions involving the phenolic -OH and lattice occluded water producing a bilayer structure wherein the 4,4′-bpy ligands are protruding on either side of the bilayer. The bilayer tapes are further packed in 3D sustained via N–H···O and O–H···O interactions involving the pyridyl N metal bound water and carboxylate O atoms ().

The coordination polymer CP5 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one ZnII, one hpdia, one 4,4'-bpy, one coordinated water, and one lattice occluded water molecule. The ZnII metal center displays slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (τ4 = 0.84), coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms, one water, and one pyridyl N atom. The hpdia ligand displays a bis-monodentate coordination resulting in a 1D-coordination polymeric chain along the a-axis; the monocoordinated 4,4'-bpy remains on one side of the 1D chain; such 1D chains are packed in antiparallel fashion sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the phenolic -OH and lattice occluded water producing a bilayer structure wherein the 4,4'-bpy ligands are protruding on either side of the bilayer. The bilayer tapes are further packed in 3D sustained via N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the pyridyl N metal bound water and carboxylate O atoms ().

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP6 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of half of ZnII located on an inversion center, one fully occupied hpdia, and half of a 4,4′-bpy molecule located on an inversion center. The ZnII metal center displays distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (τ4 = 0.83), coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms and two carboxylate O atoms. Remarkably, one of the carboxylic functionalities of hpdia remains free from coordination whereas the other one is involved in coordination with the metal center thereby preventing hpdia from participating in extended coordination. The 4,4′-bpy moiety, on the other hand, acts as a bidentate ligand thereby extending the coordination network in a zigzag 1D chain; such 1D chains are further packed in parallel fashion sustained by O–H···O interactions displaying -COOH dimer synthon and phenolic -OH and carboxylate hydrogen bonding interactions ().

Crystal Structure of [Zn0.5(hpdia)(μ-4,4'-bpy)0.5]∞ (CP6)

The coordination polymer CP6 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of half of ZnII located on an inversion center, one fully occupied hpdia, and half of a 4,4'-bpy molecule located on an inversion center. The ZnII metal center displays distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (τ4 = 0.83), coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms and two carboxylate O atoms. Remarkably, one of the carboxylic functionalities of hpdia remains free from coordination whereas the other one is involved in coordination with the metal center thereby preventing hpdia from participating in extended coordination. The 4,4'-bpy moiety, on the other hand, acts as a bidentate ligand thereby extending the coordination network in a zigzag 1D chain; such 1D chains are further packed in parallel fashion sustained by O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions displaying -COOH dimer synthon and phenolic -OH and carboxylate hydrogen bonding interactions ().

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP7 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two CdII, two hpdia, one 4,4′-bpy, two coordinated water molecules, and two lattice occluded water molecules. Both of the CdII metal centers display distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by carboxylate O atoms and pyridyl N atom in equatorial position wherein the axial positions are occupied by carboxylate O atom and coordinated water. The hpdia ligand displays a tridentate bridging mode with one carboxylate chelating (μ1-η1:η1), while the other bridges two CdII atoms with each oxygen atom in monodentate fashion (μ2-η1:η1) resulting in a 1D loop chain topology along the a-axis; such chains are further bridged by the 4,4′-bpy ligand resulting in an overall 2D-coordination network. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion further sustained by intersheet O–H···O interactions involving the phenolic O–H, solvate H2O, and carboxylate O atoms and also π···π stacking (Cg···Cg = 3.586 and 3.691 Å, involving the aryl rings of hpdia). The overall network may best be described as a uninodal four-connected framework as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: The coordination polymer CP8 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. elements.content: The salient features of the crystal structures of the CPs are enlisted in . A majority of the crystals display the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The sodium salt of hpdia turned out to be an alkali coordination polymer (CP1) displaying a 2D network. In a number of cases (CP2/DCC3 and CP5/CP6), concomitant formation of different coordination polymers was observed; concomitant isolation of 1D-coordination polymer CP2 and discrete metalla-macrocyle DCC3 clearly provide evidence of dynamic ring-opening polymerization in such a reaction mixture as also observed by Puddephatt et al. The main difference in the concomitantly formed CPs, namely, CP5 and CP6, is in the coordination mode of hpdia and 4,4′-bpy; while hpdia is extending the coordination in CP5 keeping the 4,4′-bpy monodentate, the reverse is observed in CP6. Despite having the molar ratio of 1:1:1 (metal:hpdia:4,4′-bpy/bpe) in the cases of CP5–CP8, only CP7 and CP8 resulted in the expected 2D-coordination network. However, most interestingly, a majority of the CPs (the only exceptions being DCC3 and CP6) are lattice occluded molecular solids as envisaged; in all such cases, the lattice occluded guest is water, and it is hydrogen bonded with the phenolic -OH, carboxylate, and pyridyl N. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) also corroborated with the results obtained from SXRD data (see , Figures S14–S21). In the cases of CP1 and CP5, the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids and simulated PXRDs from SXRD data were near superimposable thereby establishing their crystalline phase purity. However, that was not true for the cases of CP7 and CP8; while some of the major peaks did correspond well between the patterns, there were quite a few peaks which did not match well indicating the possibility of loss of lattice occluded solvents during sample preparation (grinding) leading to such mismatch. In the cases of concomitantly formed coordination compounds (CP2/DCC3 and CP5/CP6), significant mismatch between the patterns was noticed. This could be because of the possibility of contamination of the other concomitantly formed compounds during handpicked harvesting for sample preparation for PXRD experiments (see , Figures S22–S27).

The main difference in the concomitantly formed CPs, namely, CP5 and CP6, is in the coordination mode of hpdia and 4,4'-bpy; while hpdia is extending the coordination in CP5 keeping the 4,4'-bpy monodentate, the reverse is observed in CP6. Despite having the molar ratio of 1:1:1 (metal:hpdia:4,4'-bpy/bpe) in the cases of CP5-CP8, only CP7 and CP8 resulted in the expected 2D-coordination network. However, most interestingly, a majority of the CPs (the only exceptions being DCC3 and CP6) are lattice occluded molecular solids as envisaged; in all such cases, the lattice occluded guest is water, and it is hydrogen bonded with the phenolic -OH, carboxylate, and pyridyl N. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) also corroborated with the results obtained from SXRD data (see , Figures S14-S21). In the cases of CP1 and CP5, the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids and simulated PXRDs from SXRD data were near superimposable thereby establishing their crystalline phase purity. However, that was not true for the cases of CP7 and CP8; while some of the major peaks did correspond well between the patterns, there were quite a few peaks which did not match well indicating the possibility of loss of lattice occluded solvents during sample preparation (grinding) leading to such mismatch. In the cases of concomitantly formed coordination compounds (CP2/DCC3 and CP5/CP6), significant mismatch between the patterns was noticed. This could be because of the possibility of contamination of the other concomitantly formed compounds during handpicked harvesting for sample preparation for PXRD experiments (see , Figures S22-S27).

Encouraged by the single crystal structures of the CPs of which the majority displayed lattice occluded solvents, we undertook gelation experiments of the reactants of the coordination polymers/compound (). Usually for any given gelator, the solvent for gelation and crystallization is not the same. During gelation, instead of single crystals, nano-/microfibers are formed, which are most often kinetically controlled whereas single crystal formation is thermodynamically driven. In a few cases, however, single crystals of gelator molecules were obtained from gel upon aging or from a very dilute solution of the gelator molecule in gelling solvent. Thus, after several trials, by changing the solvent system from DMF/MeOH/water, 1:1:3 (v/v/v) to DMF/water and DMSO/water, 1:4 (v/v)), gelation in all the cases was observed. As a control experiment, we also tested the gelation ability of hpdia and found that it could also gel aqueous solvents (DMF/water and DMSO/water 1:9 (v/v) ratios) and the gelation was thermo-reversible. The fact that all of the gels obtained from the reaction mixture of the CPs were thermo-irreversible clearly indicated that they were coordination polymer based metallogels and not the supramolecular gel of hpdia wherein the other reactants were simply entrapped. The aqueous gel of hpdia turned out to be quite efficient displaying 1.0 wt % minimum gelator concentration (MGC) with gel–sol dissociation temperature, T gel, of 69 °C (for DMF/water) and 73 °C (for DMSO/water). Gelation by hpdia was also pH sensitive. At acidic pH = 2, the gelation was more efficient compared to that of in neutral pH (0.5 wt % MGC). Typical T gel vs gelator concentration plot supported the supramolecular nature of the gel network as T gel increased steadily with the indication of a plateau at higher concentration (). The MGCs of the metallogels were found to be in the range of 2.4–3.7 wt % for the DMF/water solvent system and 4.0–5.2% for the DMSO/water solvent system, considering all of the reactants. In a typical experiment, DMF solution of the ligand(s) was mixed with aqueous solution of the metal salt at room temperature so that the metal/ligand/coligand molar ratio was 1:1:1 and the resulting DMF/water ratio was 1:4 (v/v). The gel was formed almost instantaneously by sonicating for ca. 20 s, which was visually confirmed by the tube inversion test.

elements.content: The morphology of the gel fibers was studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The dried gels were prepared by smearing a small amount of the gel (MGC) on the SEM stub and keeping it overnight at room temperature for air drying. SEM analysis revealed significant differences in the morphology of the gel fibers. While hpdia, CP2/DCC3, and CP5/CP6 CP8 displayed 1D fiber morphology, CP4 and CP7 showed aggregation of short plates ().

elements.content: There is no room for debate that designing a priori a gelator molecule that would predictably gel a given solvent is extremely difficult if not impossible in the near foreseeable future. However, there have been efforts to formulate a rational approach given the current understanding of gelation. The present study deals with metallogelation which is very different from supramolecular organogelation. In metallogealtion, along with various other supramolecular interactions, metal–ligand coordination is also operative in gel network formation. Moreover, the target solvent is aqueous instead of organic solvent as in organogelation. Since water is both a good hydrogen bond donor and an acceptor, it is expected that, in such gelation (aqueous gelation), the gelling solvent water also takes part in gel network formation which can happen if water molecules become a part of the crystalline lattice (assuming the gel network crystalline) as in lattice occluded molecular solids. Thus, we selected mixed ligand systems wherein the structural features of the ligand (hpdia) were chosen in such a manner that the resultant coordination compounds were expected to form lattice inclusion crystals. In fact, out of the eight coordination compounds (CP1, CP2, DCC3, CP4–CP8), five compounds (i.e., 62.5%) were lattice inclusion materials wherein the occluded solvent was water as guests in the crystal lattice. Remarkably, as envisaged, a majority of the cases (seven out of eight, i.e., 87.5%) did show gelation; the only exceptions were DCC3 and CP6 which were not lattice occluded solids yet still displayed gelation ability. As PXRD in combination with SXRD data failed to produce any conclusive results on the structure of the gel network because of various structural reasons (vide supra), it was not possible to provide direct proof of the hypothesis based on which the metallogels were designed. However, the results presented herein do indicate that there could be a link, between the crystal structures and metallogelation although not fully established.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

There is no room for debate that designing a priori a gelator molecule that would predictably gel a given solvent is extremely difficult if not impossible in the near foreseeable future. However, there have been efforts to formulate a rational approach given the current understanding of gelation. The present study deals with metallogelation which is very different from supramolecular organogelation. In metallogealtion, along with various other supramolecular interactions, metal-ligand coordination is also operative in gel network formation. Moreover, the target solvent is aqueous instead of organic solvent as in organogelation. Since water is both a good hydrogen bond donor and an acceptor, it is expected that, in such gelation (aqueous gelation), the gelling solvent water also takes part in gel network formation which can happen if water molecules become a part of the crystalline lattice (assuming the gel network crystalline) as in lattice occluded molecular solids. Thus, we selected mixed ligand systems wherein the structural features of the ligand (hpdia) were chosen in such a manner that the resultant coordination compounds were expected to form lattice inclusion crystals. In fact, out of the eight coordination compounds (CP1, CP2, DCC3, CP4-CP8), five compounds (i.e., 62.5%) were lattice inclusion materials wherein the occluded solvent was water as guests in the crystal lattice. Remarkably, as envisaged, a majority of the cases (seven out of eight, i.e., 87.5%) did show gelation; the only exceptions were DCC3 and CP6 which were not lattice occluded solids yet still displayed gelation ability. As PXRD in combination with SXRD data failed to produce any conclusive results on the structure of the gel network because of various structural reasons (vide supra), it was not possible to provide direct proof of the hypothesis based on which the metallogels were designed. However, the results presented herein do indicate that there could be a link, between the crystal structures and metallogelation although not fully established.

To a solution of dimethyl-5-aminoisophthalate (10 mmol, 2.1 g) in 20 mL of H2O was added 1 mL of concentrated HCl; the solution was cooled to 5 °C. A solution of NaNO2 (11 mmol, 0.75 g) in 2 mL of ice cold water was added dropwise with vigorous stirring. In a separate flask, a mixture of phenol (12 mmol, 1.13 g) and CH3COONa (110 mmol, 9 g) in 20 mL of ice water was prepared. The diazonium solution was added to the phenolic solution dropwise over 20 min with vigorous stirring. The mixture was allowed to warm up to room temperature naturally and then filtered and washed with distilled water (3 × 100 mL). The orange-red precipitate was air-dried to yield 2.9 g, 92% dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalate. In a typical hydrolysis reaction dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalate was added to a round-bottom flask containing methanol (150 mL). An aqueous NaOH solution (6 g in 20 mL of H2O) was added to this mixture and then refluxed at 50 °C/(12 h). The solution was acidified to pH = 1 using concentrated HCl. The precipitate was separated by filtration and washed with cold H2O to yield 2.5 g, 88% 5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)­isophthalic acid. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C14H10N2O5 (%): C, 58.74; H, 3.52; N, 9.79. Found: C, 58.61; H, 3.58; N, 9.69. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 10.51 (s), 8.54 (s), 8.45 (2H, s), 7.88–7.86 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz), 6.98–6.96 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz). 13C NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 166.82, 161.80, 152.13, 145.10, 134.23, 131.15, 125.71, 125.28, 116.16. UV–vis λmax (nm): 349, 249, 237. ESI-MS. Calcd for C14H10N2O5: 287.24 (M + 1). Found: [M + Na]+ 309.04. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1, ): 3390, 1704, 1600, 1506, 1417, 1319, 1271, 1234, 1149, 1108, 979, 919, 838, 759, 744, 605.

Syntheses and Characterization of CPs[(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>Na<sub>2</sub>(μ-hpdia)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> (CP1)

Na-hpdia was obtained by reacting hpdia with NaOH in 1:2 molar ratios in aqueous solution and drying. X-ray quality crystals of CP1 were grown by slow evaporation of dilute ethanolic solution of Na-hpdia at room temperature. After 3 weeks X-ray quality needle shaped orange crystals were obtained. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C56H42N8Na2O24 (%): C, 53.51; H, 3.37; N, 8.91. Found: C, 52.99; H, 3.48; N, 8.87. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3267, 3083, 1716, 1591, 1504, 1409, 1338, 1263, 1222, 1149, 1105, 977, 918, 837, 761, 746, 680.

[{(H<sub>2</sub>O)­Zn­(μ-hpdia)­(2,2′-bpy)}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>∞</sub> (CP2) and [(H<sub>2</sub>O)­Zn<sub>2</sub>(μ-hpdia)<sub>2</sub>(2,2′-bpy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub> (DCC3)

CP2 and DCC3 were obtained concomitantly under solvothermal condition from a DMF/methanol/water solution (1:2:3) of a mixture of hpdia (28.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.01 mmol) and 2,2′-bpy (15.7 mg, 0.01 mmol). The mixture was taken in a 25 mL torsion vial, heated at 75 °C for 48 h, and allowed to cool slowly. After cooling, block shaped yellow crystals were isolated (). Elem. Anal. Calcd for C24H20N4O7Zn (CP2; %): C, 53.20; H, 3.72; N, 10.34. Found: C, 53.55; H, 3.43; N, 10.36. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3353, 1600, 1554, 1539, 1440, 1371, 1249, 1145, 1025, 845, 763, 730. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C48H34N8O11Zn2 (DCC3; %): C, 55.99; H, 3.32; N, 10.88. Found: C, 55.42; H, 3.39; N, 10.54. [{(H<sub>2</sub>O)­Cd­(μ-hpdia)­(2,2′-bpy)}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>∞</sub> (CP4)

CP4 was obtained under solvothermal condition from a DMF/methanol/water solution (1:2:3) of a mixture of hpdia (28.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (31 mg, 0.01 mmol), and 2,2′-bpy (15.7 mg, 0.01 mmol) similar to CP2. cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of hpdia (5-(4-Hydroxyphenylazo)isophthalic Acid)

To a solution of dimethyl-5-aminoisophthalate (10 mmol, 2.1 g) in 20 mL of H2O was added 1 mL of concentrated HCl; the solution was cooled to 5 °C. A solution of NaNO2 (11 mmol, 0.75 g) in 2 mL of ice cold water was added dropwise with vigorous stirring. In a separate flask, a mixture of phenol (12 mmol, 1.13 g) and CH3COONa (110 mmol, 9 g) in 20 mL of ice water was prepared. The diazonium solution was added to the phenolic solution dropwise over 20 min with vigorous stirring. The mixture was allowed to warm up to room temperature naturally and then filtered and washed with distilled water (3 × 100 mL). The orange-red precipitate was air-dried to yield 2.9 g, 92% dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)isophthalate. In a typical hydrolysis reaction dimethyl-5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)isophthalate was added to a round-bottom flask containing methanol (150 mL). An aqueous NaOH solution (6 g in 20 mL of H2O) was added to this mixture and then refluxed at 50 °C/(12 h). The solution was acidified to pH = 1 using concentrated HCl. The precipitate was separated by filtration and washed with cold H2O to yield 2.5 g, 88% 5-(4-hydroxyphenylazo)isophthalic acid. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C14H10N2O5 (%): C, 58.74; H, 3.52; N, 9.79. Found: C, 58.61; H, 3.58; N, 9.69. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 10.51 (s), 8.54 (s), 8.45 (2H, s), 7.88-7.86 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz), 6.98-6.96 (2H, d, J = 7.2 Hz). 13C NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, ): δ 166.82, 161.80, 152.13, 145.10, 134.23, 131.15, 125.71, 125.28, 116.16. UV-vis λmax (nm): 349, 249, 237. ESI-MS. Calcd for C14H10N2O5: 287.24 (M + 1). Found: [M + Na]+ 309.04. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1, ): 3390, 1704, 1600, 1506, 1417, 1319, 1271, 1234, 1149, 1108, 979, 919, 838, 759, 744, 605.

Syntheses and Characterization of CPs

[(H2O)4Na2(μ-hpdia)4]∞ (CP1)

Na-hpdia was obtained by reacting hpdia with NaOH in 1:2 molar ratios in aqueous solution and drying. X-ray quality crystals of CP1 were grown by slow evaporation of dilute ethanolic solution of Na-hpdia at room temperature. After 3 weeks X-ray quality needle shaped orange crystals were obtained. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C56H42N8Na2O24 (%): C, 53.51; H, 3.37; N, 8.91. Found: C, 52.99; H, 3.48; N, 8.87. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3267, 3083, 1716, 1591, 1504, 1409, 1338, 1263, 1222, 1149, 1105, 977, 918, 837, 761, 746, 680.

[{(H2O)Zn(μ-hpdia)(2,2'-bpy)}⋅H2O]∞ (CP2) and [(H2O)Zn2(μ-hpdia)2(2,2'-bpy)2]2 (DCC3)

CP2 and DCC3 were obtained concomitantly under solvothermal condition from a DMF/methanol/water solution (1:2:3) of a mixture of hpdia (28.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.01 mmol) and 2,2'-bpy (15.7 mg, 0.01 mmol). The mixture was taken in a 25 mL torsion vial, heated at 75 °C for 48 h, and allowed to cool slowly. After cooling, block shaped yellow crystals were isolated (). Elem. Anal. Calcd for C24H20N4O7Zn (CP2; %): C, 53.20; H, 3.72; N, 10.34. Found: C, 53.55; H, 3.43; N, 10.36. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3353, 1600, 1554, 1539, 1440, 1371, 1249, 1145, 1025, 845, 763, 730. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C48H34N8O11Zn2 (DCC3; %): C, 55.99; H, 3.32; N, 10.88. Found: C, 55.42; H, 3.39; N, 10.54. For concomitant compounds, the corresponding crystals were handpicked under a microscope for elemental analysis. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3158, 1614, 1587, 1558, 1506, 1477, 1446, 1361, 1269, 1213, 1139, 847, 765, 732.

[{(H2O)Cd(μ-hpdia)(2,2'-bpy)}⋅H2O]∞ (CP4)

CP4 was obtained under solvothermal condition from a DMF/methanol/water solution (1:2:3) of a mixture of hpdia (28.6 mg, 0.01 mmol), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (31 mg, 0.01 mmol), and 2,2'-bpy (15.7 mg, 0.01 mmol) similar to CP2. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3419, 3064, 1591, 1463, 1384, 1247, 1016, 825, 773, 734.

cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure illustration of CP2: (a) 1D chain; (b) packing of hydrogen bonded 1D chains to form 2D sheets, with voids occupied by solvate water (red balls).

cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure illustration of DCC3: (a) discrete coordination complex; (b) packing of stacks of coordination complex via hydrogen bonding.
